description:
Objective: be the first player reaching target zone (space 60)
-    acting by turns –

Each player rolls the die and steps forward.

Ending on a marked space follow instructions glued into the lid.

Notes:
Likely published late 1920s
Cute pewter pawns

Wing It - The overland, underhand birdwatching challenge.

Race around the British countryside to be the first to spot unusual birds and at the same time hamper other players to prevent them from getting there first.

A Chough has just landed at the RSPB reserve on Ramsey Island and as you jump in your boat to be the first to get there you discover one of your opponents has hidden your paddles. However, don’t worry, they can’t get there either, because you’ve just punctured the tyres on their bike.

Wing It is a great fun family board game, requiring a little cunning, some guile and the employment of underhand tactics in order to win. Utilising official RSPB illustrations, calling on the experience of RSPB wardens and using actual RSPB reserves, Wing It  combines an authentic birdwatching game with family entertainment.

You might ruffle a few feathers but remember the early bird wins.

There are 4 starting points in this game: London, Lublin, Serajewo and Tarragona. From there the players have to travel to Rome. The city cards are dealt to the players and determine, which cities the player has to visit on his way to Rome. The players get a number of game coins, which they can lose on some spaces on the game board.

The first player to reach Rome gets the first prize. The second prize gets to the player with the most game coins.

The game was most likely published in the 1950s.

Objective: place most of your markers upon the board; improve the multiplication up to 100.
 - acting by turns –

Each player gets his/her coloured markers/chips and rolls the 4 dice (with numbers up to 10):

Form a square with the 4 dice and multiply either the horizontal, vertical or diagonal numbers:

Both results may be marked with your chips on the board. Achieving a 9, 25, 49 or 81 you have a second turn, a ‘100’ gives you a third turn. If you cannot use numbers you loose that turn, game ends after all numbers are marked.

Note:
Likely published during 1930's

Observation game which stimulates the concentration. Find the common element on the displayed cards.ï»¿ The same hat, same cheeks or same jumper : three ways to combine cats and win the game by getting rid of all your cards.

Henchling is an epic and hilarious strategy card game that can be played with up to 4 awesome people!

You are a fearsome Henchling Overlord waging war against friend and foe to become the most powerful Overlord around (or at least the last one standing). Play your Henchlings in order to amass a powerful force and defeat your opponent.  But don't worry, when henchlings themselves are not enough, you can call on a wide assortment of amusing items and terrifying spells to lay low your enemies!

With a mix of classic TCG and CCG mechanics, Henchling does away with boosters and money-grubbing to provide a wilder, faster, and funnier card gaming experience without the hefty price tag. One set of 120 unique cards will power you and your friends through hundreds of play sessions with huge diversity, surprising depth, and hilarious outcomes.

God Hates Charades is a fast-paced acting and guessing party game that will have you and your friends acting like "God auditioning for the role of a dead body on Law And Order", "Batman having too much fun at a glory hole", or maybe "Jeff Goldblum complaining that MTV doesn't play music videos."

Whatever the scene, you'll be laughing so hard your face will melt off like those Nazi jerks in Raiders of the Lost Ark.

Kingdoms in Peril is a multi-strategy card game set in 700BC that can be played with 2 to 6 players. Players create a Kingdom through selecting City Cards that vary in strength and risk.

Players choose a Kingdom and then select City Cards that vary in strength. These cities are placed onto the game table and make up each player's Kingdom. Players collect and purchase various cards to build a playing card hand, which will be used during game play to battle opponents over cities. There are also some special feature cards in the mix, as well as prized Defensive Cards that allow a player to surrender to an opponent and pay tribute rather than lose a valuable city to defeat..

Throughout the game players must balance their army (playing hand), resources (gold), and siege weapons (keys). While strategizing how to use various Battle Strength Cards to fend off attackers and defeat opponents in Battle.

Players slip into the role of penguins who try to collect as many ice floes as they can while trying not to fall off the iceberg, which is becoming smaller and smaller with every round.

Each movement must be well thought out, because on the slippery ice each movement will also have an effect for the next round. The movement you perform on Round 1 will become your momentum for the next round, and so on.

But that’s not all. You must also imagine the intention of your opponents, because if a penguin collides with another penguin, it will transfer its momentum to the other penguin.

The game ends as the last penguin falls into the water. The player with the highest pile of ice floes wins the game.

The game was nominated for the "Landespreis für Spielkultur 2010" (State Award for Board Game Culture) awarded by Styria (Austria) under its German name "Eisberg".

Now you've done it...you pushed Olivia a little too far! Move Olivia around a self destructing grid of 5x5 cards and have her catch your opponents before they have her catch you! Survive three rounds of play to be the winner!

Players draw cards not from a deck, but from a board that Olivia starts the game in the middle of. Players can then move Olivia around the board by swapping her card with other cards. The board gets progressively smaller as the game goes on, a mechanic you need to use to your advantage to knock out other players or end rounds while you're ahead on points. Drawn cards allow you to move Olivia, discard cards from the board, secretly swap the card in your hand with one on the board, and, eventually, have Olivia catch other players who are not protected by any cards between them and her!

Every round the cards that are available change, so your strategy can switch between heavy offense, strategic card removals, and unofficial alliances with other players to knock out those who are further ahead. If two or more players survive the round, the values of their discarded cards determine the winner.

A family game for 2-4 players about becoming the head chef in the world famous "Burrito! Burrito!" restaurant.

The world famous Tex-Mex Restaurant “Burrito! Burrito!” is looking for a new head chef. As an up-and-coming chef, this is a huge opportunity for you. However, you are not alone in your quest to become world renowned. 
The restaurant owners are running an open competition to find the right chef for the job, and you will have to compete with other chefs, for the position. The task is simple; be the most productive and resourceful chef to complete the last fajita and the job will be yours.

Chefs will compete to be the first to complete 5 finished fajitas. The first chef to fulfill their fifth fajita order is the winner.

Speed â€‹â€‹Cups² can be played on its own with two players, but it can also serve as an expansion for Quick Cups, which then allows for play with up to six players.

In this game, each player receives a set of five plastic cups, each a different color; a deck of 24 cards is shuffled and placed face down in the center of the table next to the bell. One player flips over the top card, which depicts colored objects – trains, birds, cups, etc. – stacked vertically or horizontally, then everyone tries to recreate this colored sequence with her own set of cups. The first player to do slams the bell, revels in the soul-brightening "ding", then (if correct), claims the card. Someone then reveals the next card, and the players start shuffling cups once again.

In Speed â€‹â€‹Cups² you don't only have to arrange your cups in horizontal and vertical stacks, but you also have to make different stacks!

T.V. tie-in game for the BBC series Wallace & Gromit: World of Invention. "Start a space race and build a rocket with this cracking family game!"

A simple roll and move with 2.5D rocket models that slot together. The winner is the first player to collect all the pieces of their rocket. No tactical or strategic decisions with more random noise added by "Chance" cards that hinder, help, allow "take that" or defend from it.

The Dictionary is filled with words you may or may not have heard of. They are the words you used to look up on the internet or call each other when you were young. They are vulgar, sexual, positional, provocative, and just crazy. You will ask yourself, "do people actually do these things?" at least once every game.

But watch out, not every card in the Dictionary is Lewd and Obscene. Your creativity may get ahead of yourself. In that sense, you'll need to "get your mind out of the gutter."


Lewd and Obscene is an adult party game.

The game begins by picking a card from the Dictionary. The word is read aloud but the definition remains a mystery to everyone except the picker.

Players try their best to define the word. They write their made-up definition to the word on their "Definition Slip".

When all players are finished defining words, the slips are turned in, mixed up, and read aloud. After all definitions have been read, voting takes place.

When voting, tally points on the definition slip. If you convince a player to vote for your definition, you receive one (1) point. If you vote for the correct definition, you receive two (1) points. Once all the scores are collected, the next player picks a new card and starts all over.

Upon starting, you will all agree to a score to end on and once that has been reached, you will have your winner.

Christina Regina - the Board Game is a game about politics and intrigues in 17th century Sweden where each player represents a faction with a hidden agenda. The end of their intrigues is the newly appointed queen Christina of Sweden and their means include persuasion, agitation, manipulation and even assassination. This is achieved by carefully steering the queen towards influence tiles bearing their faction colors and away from other influence tiles. At the same time, they must closely monitor the other players' actions to guess their agendas. But beware, if your own agenda is too obvious, you may yourself become the victim of your opponents' intrigues!

Game mechanisms include:

1. Tile laying: Tiles are laid at the start of the game and make every session unique. 
2. Asymmetric scoring: There are no "good" or "bad" tiles but they all score differently for different players. 
3. Hidden agendas: The players do not know how much the other players score until the very end. 
4. Guessing game: Based on how players play, the other players may gain points by guessing their agendas (or lose points by guessing wrong).

Christina Regina is the third game in the Nova Suecia series.

Migration is a game suitable for 2-4 players, in which each player takes the role of multiple anthropomorphic animals migrating to a new continent. Players take turns to place an animal token on the board, representing towns. Each new town must originate from the last town placed (with certain exceptions). Each animal token has a unique ability, introducing a high degree of strategy. The game is over when no player is able to make a legal move, and points are scored for each town on the board. The player with the highest score wins.

Migration: Book II – A Saga of Conflict includes both Book I and a new Book II. There are new mechanics since the Game Crafter version including: Age Cards, an optional drafting mechanism, a modular board, additional terrain modifiers, and six new explorer types.

Mysterious Creatures was created to engage player's curiosity in the mysteries of nature that exist across the world. The game takes each player on an adventure/race across the globe in search of their creature's evidence cards.  The first player to collect all 3 evidence cards and make it back to their creature's country of origin wins! Along the way players will learn geography, country flags and multiple creatures such as Big Foot.

The game 'Become the prime minister' gets you in the battle of politics! You have to propose innovative and convincing ideas for society problems, so that you gain good evaluation numbers!

Moreover you have to keep good relationships with your rivals... Tactics and politics are closely related.

Every candidate moves using a dice and takes the  corresponding card. He reads the problem, and starts setting up arguments and concluding to a solution for the problem. As soon as he finishes, everybody evaluate his speech with their available card numbers (positive, neutral or even negative). You don't want negative evaluations in your hands at the end of the game...

The player with the greatest sum of evaluations after 3 rounds wins the game.

Lists is a very pleasant trivia game!

Every player has to place in the right order some answers in the card that is being played.

An example could be chronological order of some events, or American presidents, right order from the longest river to the shortest one, right order from the movie with the most Oscars to the one with the least. The answers are given. You'll have just to place them in the right order.

Depending on your right answers in the row, you move along the board till the finish line!

Invazions is an asymmetric card game.

One player embodies what is left of the human race, whereas all of the other players cooperate as zombies hordes. Goals and gameplays are different for each side. Manage your resources and find the cure, or improve your hoard with a new deckbuilding system and free the zombies captured for genetic experiments, the choice is yours!

Space Racing Game is a tactical racing game in which players take control of powerful space ships, facing them against each other. Players race simulated space ships with the hope of crossing the finish line first.

Each ship has its own unique maneuvers and powers.

At start of the game the players will buy ships and components.

Space Racing Game is a tactical game of miniatures, cards and dice which takes place in two phases: 
1. Planning
2. Moving

Planning phase:     at the same time each Player secretly chooses one maneuver and speed using dial.

After Planning phase, each Player move their ships and use its powers.

In sequential order all Players perform their “Moving phase” (Player initiative).

Moving phase: the player has to use a move template and move their space ship, which was secretly chosen.

Players take penalties if they miss their maneuvers, bump into another ship, are blocked by other ships.
The player with the most game points wins the game.

Space Racing Game has 3 different scenarios (racing types) and each of them has its own set of special rules and victory conditions. 
 However, the fun does not end with a single race! The game rules include the ability to customize your ships and change ships components types to modify your speed, maneuvers, powers and special abilities.
 You should plan your strategy, and complete your mission!

Ta Ziemia (This Land) is a family, cooperative board game. It allows players to move back to the year 1979 and participate in the preparations for the first pilgrimage of Polish Pope John Paul II to his homeland plunged in the complicated reality of communism.

The task set for the players in Ta Ziemia is not easy: they must confront the forces of the communist regime, which hinder the organization of the pilgrimage and try to diminish its importance. Players work together to help in preparations for the visit of John Paul II. Acting under pressure of time and the communist regime, players must show cleverness, imagination and the ability to predict opponent's next moves.

Box contains:
- Board
- 44 Renovation cards
- 44 Regime cards
- 10 Central regime cards
- 8 Special city rules cards
- 4 Faction cards
- 16 Citizen pawns
- 1 Time marker
- 15 Influence tiles
- 15 Faith tiles
- 15 Resistance tiles
- 30 Faithful tiles
- 8 Agent tiles
- Instruction

Mesa is an original deck of whimsical, fantasy-adventure cards that allows for a variety of game-play. The deck consists of 48 cards, 42 Character cards and 6 Object cards.

Each card has a set of three Attributes: Value, Power and Clan. Value Attribute is the general value of the card. Power Attribute is a specific break-down of a character's/object's strength. It is expressed on a 3×3 grid and shows six different categories: Body, Mind, Spirit, Land, Water, and Air. The Clan Attribute shows the cards suit. There are six different Clans and each Clan has its own unique symbol.

Currently, there are 9 different games for the Mesa deck. They are the following: "Playground Wars", "Heroic Dreams", "Revolution", "Great Escape", "Power of Love", "Save the Baby", "Mesa Puzzle", "Tower Building Babel", "Mesa Patterns".

Integrates With:

Mesa Grown-ups Playing Cards

Wabbits are everywhere! And their fearless leader, the Wa Wabbit, is planning to continue his invasion all the way to your house!
 Discover the MiFuChi game: Win duels, lure the Wa Wabbit into your camp, and pilfer his treasure - the first player to collect all three of the Wa Wabbit's treasures wins!

A reworking of ShiFuMi, the rock-paper-scissors game, and set in the world of Dofus, players compete in rounds of rock-paper-scissors or throw down card combos to move the Wa Wabbit.

3 rocks/leaves/scissors: Move the Wa Wabbit 1 space towards your camp
3 carrots: Move the Wa Wabbit 3 spaces towards your camp
3 Lenalds: Take a treasure

When making a combo, the Dofus is like a Joker - it can be a rock, leaf, scissors, or carrot (but not a Lenald).

When the Wa Wabbit reaches the end of the board, the player wins an item in the array. The game ends when one player receives three.

The cards that a player receive for winning a round give the player a bonus (each different, and detailed on the card). 
 . 
Included in the box : 50 game cards + 3 treasure cards, a puzzle gameboard and the Wa Wabbit Figurine.

[First paragraph of the rules translated from French to English]

In this game, plants fight to survive in a formalised jungle, taking control of the area and eliminating opponent plants. Two to five players can play on the board showing 304 hexagons, with each player in possession of 50 growth counters and 3 seed counters.

Objective: be the first to get the permanent majority of votes for the coming election of the mayor - learn more about the city of Hannover
- moving/acting by turns.

Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instructions of space landed on; buys, if possible and/or (preferable) votes.

"Chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Hannover. Correct answers give economic advantages.

Voting process about the next mayor: Each owned company corresponds to a number of votes. The results of each voting are kept and the final winner is the first player who reaches the target.

Objective: be the first to get the permanent majority of votes for the coming election of the mayor - learn more about the city of Itzehoe
- moving/acting by turns.

Each player rolls the die, moves according the number, follows instructions of space landed on; buys, if possible and/or (preferable) votes.

"Chance" cards are created with circumstances out of the history of Itzehoe. Correct answers give economic advantages.

Voting process about the next mayor: Each owned company corresponds to a number of votes. The results of each voting are kept and the final winner is the first player who reaches the target.

Players take the roll of stall holders at Expo, a comic book and media show, moving around the board collecting resources in order to serve the customers and get their money. The player with the most money at the end of three days is the winner.

Players can move anywhere they choose on the board but the player in last place always moves next, so it is important not to run too far ahead and give other players an advantage as they catch up to you.

Objective: be the first capturing an opponent's home base (hort) 
 - moving by turns -
each player places his/her troops - 4 dwarfs, 1 imp, 1 goblin - upon the home base/coloured spaces; troops can be moved into any direction, green spaces in the centre are save.
Try to reach one of the 2 other home bases with your goblin first: dwarfs & imps can be hit and removed by dwarfs & imps, goblins can't hit anyone, but will be beaten by imps only. If you loose your goblin you loose the game.

In Bedpans & Broomsticks, all but one of the players are the Elders of the Shady Pines Village retirement home. You are all trying to get to one of the 3 exits from the building. Another player controls the Staff of doctors, nurses, and orderlies who are trying to stop you and return you to your bed.

Each round you move your pieces on a layout consisting of room-tiles that represent the layout of the Village. You start on a single tile, but you can't remember the rest of the layout. So you place a new tile each time you look through an open, exterior corridor onto a room tile that you have not seen before. Along the way you can pick up and use Stuff-markers that you find.

This movement and exploration continues until enough of the Elders are captured or neutralized by the Staff, or until one or more of the Elders reaches an exit and escapes.

Two games in one package.


1914: Glory's End

Before the award-winning World War I designs Paths of Glory and The Great War In Europe, Deluxe Edition, designer Ted S. Raicer had revived interest in gaming the Great War with a series of WWI campaign games for the late lamented Command magazine. GMT is proud to present a set of revised boxed editions of these classic “players-games”.

In August 1914, Imperial Germany gambled its future on a rapid conquest of France, designed to free up the German army within six weeks to face the Russian steamroller of France’s Tsarist ally on the eastern front. Seven German armies deployed opposite five French armies, the army of “plucky little Belgium”, and the “Old Contemptibles” of the British Expeditionary Force in a series of battles that turned August and September 1914 into the bloodiest months of the entire war.

1914: Glory’s End covers the first three months of the Great War on the western front, from the Guns of August to First Ypres. This oft-gamed campaign receives a unique treatment, emphasizing playability without compromising on historical feel. Units are mostly corps of four steps (two counters per unit), along with a few especially strong (or weak) brigades and divisions, along with counters for the feared German Krupp and Skoda guns. The corps level Order of Battle accurately reflects the operational doctrine of the campaign, while also limiting the number of counters on the map to an easy-to-manage level.

The game scale is 9.5 miles per hex and three days per turn. The campaign game runs a full 30 turns, but the new edition will include not only a previously published mini-scenario on the Battle of the Marne, but a short ten turn campaign scenario covering the decisive opening weeks of the war. In addition the campaign games can be played in historical or free set-up versions.

1914: Glory’s End uses an Igo-Hugo system with two types of combat to demonstrate the tactical realities of the campaign: Prepared Combat and March Combat. Prepared Combat allows you to bring all your adjacent units to bear against a defending hex, but only with units that don’t move. This gives the defender time to reinforce, retreat, or pre-empt your combat with his own attack. To avoid this, you can “attack off the march” during your movement, but March Combat may only be delivered by a single stack at a time, limiting the force you can bring to bear. Furthermore, March Combat cannot be used against entrenched enemy units.

The coming of trench warfare is reflected by a unique Entrenchment rule: starting on turn 10 players may entrench one or two hexes per turn, PLUS any hexes adjacent to enemy trenches. The result is that trenches appear first as a tactical consideration, but then turn into a strategic problem as they spread with ever-increasing rapidity along the front.

1914: Glory’s End manages to cover all the important characteristics of the campaign (with rules for forts, cavalry, command and control breakdowns, supply, strategic rail movement, Allied sea movement, German forced marching, Plan XVII, Paris in Danger! and more) while remaining easy to play. The new GMT version will of course incorporate all errata from the original edition, but adds updated artwork, a corrected historical campaign Order of Battle, additional scenarios, and a tweaked set of rules.


When Eagles Fight

Before the award-winning World War I designs Paths of Glory and The Great War In Europe, Deluxe Edition, designer Ted S. Raicer had revived interest in gaming the Great War with a series of WWI campaign games for the late lamented Command magazine. GMT is proud to present a set of revised boxed editions of these classic “players-games”.

Winner of the Charles S. Roberts award for best pre-WWII boardgame, When Eagles Fight covers the eastern front in World War I, the last war of Tsarist Russia, Habsburg Austria, and Imperial Germany. From 1914 to 1917 the armies of the Tsar battled from the Carpathians to the Baltic against the outnumbered but logistically superior German army and the badly-led multi-ethnic forces of Austria-Hungary (the Central Powers). Though repeatedly inflicting massive defeats on the Habsburg armies, the Russians were ultimately undone by the skill and firepower of the German army and the collapsing political structure of the Tsarist autocracy. By March 1917 the 300 year-old Romanov dynasty was no more, and the stage was set for the coming of Lenin and the Bolsheviks. But the empire of the Habsburgs was left mortally wounded, and the Kaiser’s Germany would meet its own doom less than two years later on the battlefields of the western front.

When Eagles Fight recreates this titanic struggle from the initial clashes at Tannenberg and in Galicia to the revolution that brought down Tsar Nicholas II. The large-hex map covers the eastern front of the Great War from the northern tip of Romania to Petrograd, and from Berlin to Smolensk at a scale of 25 miles to the hex. Turns represent one or two months, and combat units range from division to (mostly) corps.

When Eagles Fight has a set of low-complexity rules, without sacrificing the historical elements of this unique theater of the Great War. The combat results table is bloody and attritional, but allows for breakthroughs with the right tactics or artillery support. The greater operational skills of the German army is shown in the use of the OberOst HQ, which allows additional attacks on a select part of the front. The Russian supreme headquarters, Stavka, in turn has the ability to concentrate their limited supplies to overcome logistical shortages. And the surprise tactics of the Brusilov Offensive can allow a late game victory over the Austrians.

Other rules cover the slow pace of Russian mobilization, Austrian Lock-Step Planning in the opening days of the war, German heavy artillery, fortifications, Russian Guards forces, Cavalry Retreats, and the effects of events on other fronts.

But the new edition of When Eagles Fight is more than just a reprint of the original version. The Random Events Table has been exchanged for a system of random events chits allowing for more events. The effects if the Germans do not launch a Verdun offensive in France-which sometimes threw off the balance of the original design- have been revised. Changes in the stacking rules after 1914 more accurately reflect the effect of trenches on the course of the campaigns. And the map now contains the rail lines removed by Command from the first edition. The game also includes a short alternative-history scenario in which the bulk of the German army goes east rather than west in August 1914.

These changes make this an improved edition of an already award-winning design. Tense, historical, and just plain fun, When Eagles Fight is a game that belongs in the collection of everyone with an interest in the Great War!

Once upon a time, there was a little town covered by enchanted mist. Different people lived in this town with a problem of always be confused about the identity of each other. Eventually, they hated each other, separating into two parties. No one wanted to give their profit to another party. Hence, each party wanted to make sure that their the power of their people is greater than another. We accidentally come to this town, and we do not want to get into the trouble of two parties confrontation. Therefore, we have to figure out which party is prior than another, and make sure that we do not choose the wrong party to give our friendly greetings.

In the enchanted mist, players are trying to figure out which party is more powerful than another by secretly check out some people's identity, changing position with specific character. Once your figure out the situation over the town, you and all opponents may speak out how powerful is the party that take control over the town. The player who accurately speak out the power might be the one bless by goddess of victory. After few rounds of game, the winner will be the one who collect the most power points.

This is a game painted by MS Office 2010 PowerPoint

40 cards, each containing one or two letters, are placed face down in the center of the table in eight stacks (four stacks in top row and four stacks in bottom row). Player ONE begins play by turning over top card of each stack, and from the 8 face up cards makes ONE word of 2-or-more letters and places it in his play area. Words are played fanned together like a Rummy hand to save space.

Player TWO (and every player thereafter) flips over any face down card atop stacks the prior player used to make their word, thereby replenishing the formation to 8 face up cards. Player TWO likewise makes ONE 2-or-more letter word and places in in his play area. However, in addition, he may steal words from other players' areas by adding one or more of the remaining letters in formation to those words (inserting at any point of word or optionally rearranging the letters in those words). Multiple play-ons are allowed each turn, and players can "play on" their own words also. Play continues with the next player. When any stack is depleted of cards, face up cards from other stacks with multiple cards are slid over to occupy open position and underneath card is flipped over to be face up.

The winner is the player with the most letters in his play area when all cards in the 8 stack formation are depleted.

80 cards total in deck. Deck is re-shuffled before each game for a fresh set of 40 cards in the formation for each round.

Play best 2-out-of-3 or 3-out-of-5 rounds (as decided by players beforehand) to determine winner of match. Each round takes about 10 minutes.

The board consists of 12 hospital rooms bordered by hallways. Into each room is placed a randomly chosen patient card, which in turn is covered with four randomly chosen cards that are turned face-up. Each of those four cards represents an ailment. Each patient's ailments must be cured in the order that the cards are stacked, top to bottom.

Each player controls a nurse, resident, intern, and attending physician. These pieces move from room to room curing the ailments and scoring points for the cures. The more difficult cures are worth more points. Interns can move the greatest distance in a turn, doctors the shortest, but doctors and residents outrank interns. Credit for a cure goes to the highest ranking doctor in a room or, in case of a tie, to the player with the most doctors in the room. Nurses can block access to rooms. The games ends when all patients are cured of all ailments. The player with the most points wins.

In the circular tray in Last One Lost — previously released as Last Mouse Lost and Pop It — players confront six rows of raised bubbles, with each row holding 3-6 bubbles. At the start of the game, all of the bubbles protrude from their holes. Taking turns, each player selects one row with one or more upraised bubbles and presses one or more of those bubbles to leave only holes. Whoever presses down the final bubble loses.

Once you finish a game, you can flip the tray to the opposite side, and you're ready to play again immediately!

Man vs. Apocalypse has 2 decks, the Scrounging Deck, and the Apocalypse Deck. The scrounging deck contains all the people and items you will need to survive.

The Apocalypse deck contains the disasters and the Apocalypses themselves, at the end of the every round one of these cards will be reveled and have to be dealt with.

At the beginning of the Man vs. Apocalypse you and your friends will draw up to a full hand(5) of cards from the Scrounging Deck. You can play as many cards as you want from your hand on your turn, but be warned, if you run out of cards in your hand you are killed and have lost the game.

As you play these cards, each survivor have special abilities that can help you, some will provide you some defense vs. a specific disaster, other may bring a useful skill, some are only useful for a time, before they must be sacrificed for the greater good(You).

On their turn a player will draw 2 cards,(no more then 5 in hand) and be place in play as many as he wants.  Once all players have gone you draw from the Apocalypse Deck, these cards will force you to discard your survivors in play, discard cards from your hand or create other chaos.

Once all players have dealt with the Disaster that was drawn, the play starts with the first player again.

The goal is to survive to the end of the Apocalypse deck, only then can you begin to rebuild.

The players begin with sets of identical blocks and place their respective blocks upright on opposite sides of a battlefield that consists either of hexes or of squares. Players take turns downing an opponent's piece (placing a piece in an unobstructed line of sight to the opponent's piece), taking out an opponent's piece (moving onto a space occupied by an opponent's downed piece and then removing that piece from the board), or restoring a downed piece (placing that piece upright in one's home area). A player wins when all of his opponent's pieces on the board are down.

In Karma, each player is dealt three face-down cards that they cannot look at and that remain on the table in front of them. They are dealt six more cards, choose three of those for their hand, and place the remaining three face-up onto their table cards in three separate stacks. One player begins by placing a card or cards of the same value from their hand onto the table face-up to create a discard pile. The other players in turn must place onto the discard stack a card or cards of the same value that match(es) or exceed(s) the value of the top card of the stack; or else, pick up the stack. Until the draw pile is gone, players must draw at the end of their turns to maintain a hand of at least three cards.

All of a player's hand cards must be played before any of their face-up table cards, which must in turn be played before any of their face-down table cards. A few cards allow players to break the foregoing rules. The last player with cards loses the game.

Karma is based on the public domain card game, Palace.

Marvel Dice Masters: Uncanny X-Men is a collectible dice-building tabletop game designed by Quarriors! creators Michael Elliott and Eric M. Lang.

In this game — which features Wolverine, Magneto, Cyclops, Iceman, Psylocke, the Sentinels and more — each player fields a superhero team, with each hero being represented by custom-tooled dice; each team must be composed of 15 dice, and a player can "purchase" dice only from his team. Each hero also has one or more character reference cards, which show the special abilities for the characters based on the die rolls. Different versions of these cards will be available in booster packs, allowing for more customization of your team. Players use these dice to collect energy, recruit new heroes, and battle head-to-head. In addition, each player brings two basic action cards to the game, which are placed in the center of the table; both players can purchase these cards. A player wins once the opposing player has been reduced to zero life.

The Marvel Dice Masters: Uncanny X-Men starter set comes with 44 custom dice, 38 cards, two dice bags, and a core rulebook. Booster packs include two dice with two matching character cards.

Get ready to exercise your fingers and your mind. Tile Pile is a Memory / Dexterity game in which players must locate lettered tiles in order to complete words and score points. Simple rules and quick gameplay make this game a fun learning tool for children and excellent party game for adults.

There are 3 Matches in the game. Each Match has 3 Rounds. Players are given cards of varying difficulty. In each Round, players search for letters to complete words of the same difficulty. First to finish hits the bell and the Round ends. Points are scored and tallied and the game continues. After the end of the third match, the game ends and final scores are totaled.

The game is played with a 5-suited deck that includes a joker, two special cards, and cards numbered 1 through 10 in each suit. It is a trick-taking game in the vein of Wizard or Oh Hell. Players bid simultaneously on the number of tricks they will take each hand. They receive a ten point bonus for being correct, zero for overbidding, and points equal to the number of tricks taken for underbidding. A player receives an additional bonus if he is dealt a special card, bids the amount shown on the card, and then makes the bid. The game ends after ten rounds. High score wins.

This is a Print&Play solo game: you are trapped in a maze filled with monsters, with only one laser-gun and two random objects, the goal in the first level is to find the three parts of the sword, and exit.

You can download all you need to play in the file section.

From the Rules:

"Battle for Fallujah: New Dawn is a simple, single player game simulating the second battle for Fallujah, Iraq. The game begins on day D+1, November 8, 2004. While fighting in Fallujah continued until the end of December, this game portrays the first seven days of battle in which Coalition forces took the most territory and faced the fiercest resistance. This simulation is intended to represent a modern, urban counterinsurgency operation.

As a player, your goal is to clear Fallujah of insurgents while searching the city, block-by-block. Time is of the essence. Meanwhile, you must maintain the political will and support of both the American and Iraqi governments. You will be combating insurgents whose goal is to inflict as many casualties as possible and force American 'infidels' from their city, and eventually, country. The conflict is contained within the city of Fallujah."

Fardh al-Qanoon is a simulation of the 2007 counterinsurgency operation in Baghdad, also referred to as the ‘Baghdad Security Plan.’ The simulation takes place from February 2007 to November 2007 in month-long turns as the US-led Coalition and Mahdi Army vie for control of the Iraqi capital.

Players & Objectives 
One player represents the Coalition, and another the Shia Mahdi Army. The Sunnis of Baghdad are represented in a non-player faction that affects the game.

The Coalition’s goal is to secure control of Baghdad’s districts and Sunni neighborhoods by November 2007 while minimizing casualties and violence. The Mahdi Army’s goal is to maintain a strong presence in Baghdad and prevent the Coalition from securing the city.

ALL ABOARD!

Iron Horses throws you back into the 19th century when Railroads dominated commerce. Climb aboard any one of Lydon Rail Company’s four railways and race to be the first train to successfully deliver $1,000,000 in resources! Be wary of what lies ahead, as setbacks are bound to happen! Tariffs will slow our delivery, maintenance will stop you in your tracks and hijackers are eager to steal your payload! Fix what you can, deliver the goods and attain victory!

Gameplay Overview:

Each player chooses one of four unique railways each with a unique advantage. During a turn, a player has up to 4 available actions, Draw, Transport, Remedy, and Sabotage, each of which will either bring you closer to victory or slow down your opponents. Your main goal is to accumulate $1,000,000 in resources before another player beats you to it. Denominations range from $25,000 to $250,000, so keep a look out for highly valued resources. But it isn't as simple as drawing and transporting resources...Setbacks can bring you to a halt. Remedy them quick to keep moving! Game play is quick, with each player allowed up to 3 actions per turn! You may draw, transport and sabotage in a turn, Draw twice and then remedy, or if you are feeling notorious, Sabotage three times! A 2-player game usually lasts about 10-15 minutes. Add a third and expect a bit longer.

Every player draws 15 flip-flop shaped pieces, each with a letter on one side and a different letter on the other. Players race to create chains of words in which the final letter(s) of one word is/are the first letter(s) of the next. Play continues until one player completes a word chain using all 15 pieces. He gets 5 points. The player with the longest word gets 10 points, and all players receive one point per word created, including nested words.

Lost Legacy: Flying Garden is a game of risk, deduction, and luck for 2–4 players. You start the game with one card in hand from a deck of sixteen cards. On a turn, you do the following:


         Draw: Draw the top card from the deck and add it to your hand.
         Play: Choose one of the two cards in hand to play and place it face up in front of you.
         Effect: Carry out the played card's effect, after which the card is considered as discarded.
         End: If there is at least one card left in the deck, the turn goes to the next player; if not, the investigation phase starts. Using the investigation speed indicated on the card each player has in hand, players take turns guessing which player (whether yourself or someone else) holds the "Lost Legacy" card; this card might also be in the "Ruins", a location that holds one card at the start of the game and possibly acquires more cards during play. The player who guesses correctly wins; if no one finds the Lost Legacy, then everybody loses.
    


By combining different Lost Legacy sets (while keeping only a single Lost Legacy card in play), up to six players can compete at the same time.

This is the English release of the 16 cards Flying Garden set in Lost Legacy with new artwork. The Starship set is released separately.

Hand Made Wonders is a party game that combines dexterity and co-operation.

Everyone wears a colored bracelet on each wrist. After the judge gives a signal, players stretch out one arm, then players form teams with the other players who stretch out an arm with a bracelet in the same color. Depending on the size of the team, the players have to form an architectural wonder by following the instructions on a card, e.g., create the Great Wall of China with a horizontal row of five hands. All players on the fastest team get a reward card for either their left or right arm, depending on what they used. The first player to collect three left and three right cards wins.

Eighteen cards bearing parts of advertisements from the 1950s. The eighteen pictures should be displayed about the room and the players write down the full name of the advertiser or product that each picture represents. The player who identifies the most with the greatest precision wins.
